utterances: It did.
It was defused.
Ken?

You know, the same thing with the famous Lloyd Bentsen about, you know, you're no Jack Kennedy line, his aides, following his death, Lloyd Bentsen's passing, his aides said they worked on - they prepared that for the moment, because they knew that Dan Quayle had been comparing himself to Jack Kennedy, that he had the same amount of experience.
So, that great line, you know, the famous Quayle deer-in-the-headlight look about, you're no Jack Kennedy, that was rehearsed well in advance.
Well, it's interesting.
The zingers are rehearsed, but as you say, Quayle looked like a deer caught in the headlights.
Mondale, at the receiving end of that quip by Reagan, which was really a joke on himself...
That's right.
Caught himself laughing hysterically and said afterwards he knew at that moment he'd just lost the election.
(Soundbite of laughter)
I think he said that softball, he just hit that out of the park.
Right.
Here's an email from Stanley in St. Louis.
A supporter once shouted out, Governor Stevenson - Adlai Stevenson, he's talking about - all thinking people are for you, and Adlai Stevenson answered, that's not enough.
I need the majority.
(Soundbite of laughter)
And that's one of the ones that is collected in your book, isn't it, Chris?
That's right.
Yeah, there's a lot of Adlai Stevenson in there.
You know...
There's a lot of Winston Churchill.
There's one Dan Quayle - I mean, Dan Quayle provides the inspiration for the book.
It could not be written without him.
(Soundbite of laughter)
You dedicated the book to Dan Quayle.
I did dedicate it to Dan Quayle.
He went from a punching bag to a punchline after the line with Bentsen.
I should say it's printed on potato paper.
How do you spell...
Yes.
You know, one of the famous ones of all time is obviously apocryphal, but it's a 1950 Senate race, Congressman George Smathers of Florida was running against Claude Pepper.
Now, everybody called him Red Pepper.
Back then, Claude Pepper was very far to the left, backed Henry Wallace in 1948, was really far to the left.

So, anyway, this was supposed to - allegedly a speech that George Smathers made in rural North Florida, and he talked about how Pepper - now, obviously, it was supposed to be an unsophisticated crowd in north Florida, so he used all these fancy words.

So, he said that Pepper was a shameless extrovert, who was known to have engaged in nepotism with his sister in law, whose sister was once a thespian, and who was acknowledged to have practiced celibacy before his marriage.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Now, to his dying day, George Smathers said he'd never said it.
It was just apocryphal, but again, a classic insult, although it never happened.
One of those stories too good to check.
Exactly.

We're talking with NPR's Political Junkie, Ken Rudin, and Chris Lamb, the editor of ""I'll Be Sober in the Morning: Great Political Comebacks, Putdowns & Ripostes."" You're listening to Talk of the Nation from NPR News.
And let's get a caller on the line.
This is Dan, Dan with us from Wildwood in Missouri.
Yes, hello.
Hi.
How are you?
Very well, thank you.
Great show.
Every Wednesday I look forward to this.
I heard one just the - last week on the Leno show.
Dustin Hoffman said that John McCain is so old that he once owned Sidney Poitier.
(Soundbite of laughter)
(Soundbite of groans)
See, he's not running for office.
Oh, I know that.
Your screener pointed it out to me, but I guess it was so good that he had to let it through.
(Soundbite of laughter)
It's a pretty good line, it's a pretty good line.
Thanks very much for that.
Obviously, not running for office, Chris, that makes a big difference.
Oh, yeah.
Yeah, I think it does.
I mean, but - a lot of these have to do with politics.
I mean, that's great inspiration, great fodder, because, you know, politics is, you know, a dog-eat-dog world, and we want to make everybody a fire hydrant.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Well, speaking of that - I can't resist the temptation here.

Democratic - then Democratic presidential challenger, referring to then Republican Vice President Dan Quayle, who had described himself going out on the stump, and he was going to be the pit bull of the campaign.
(Soundbite of press conference)
Former President BILL CLINTON: That's how he characterized himself.
He says, I'm the pit bull dog of this campaign.
I've told some people here at home that that's got every fire hydrant in America scared to death.
(Soundbite of laughter)
And that one, well, the guy who got off the good quip actually won that election.
Yeah, that's right, yeah.

One of my favorites in your book is there are three living former presidents, Jimmy Carter, Gerald Ford, and Richard Nixon, standing side by side at a White House reception during the Reagan administration.
Observing the three standing together, Senator Bob Dole said, well, there they are, see no evil, hear no evil, and evil.
(Soundbite of laughter)

There was a governor of Massachusetts named Endicott Peabody, and his - not not the smartest guy in the world, shall we say, and his challenger once said that he was named after three cities in Massachusetts, Endicott, Peabody, and Marblehead.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Dawn breaks on Marblehead.
That's right.
Let's get somebody here in the Newseum.
